review: I have read most of Hemingway's books, but it is a long time since I read his first novel, "A Farewell to Arms." So I re-read it to start the year. ItI have read most of Hemingway's books, but it is a long time since I read his first novel, "A Farewell to Arms." So I re-read it to start the year. It is a gripping anti-war story wrapped together with an idyllic love affair, and reflects Hemingway's own experience as an ambulance driver during the First World War in Italy.What struck me most in revisiting this classic were:a) The excellence of the writing. Later on Hemingway became preoccupied with stripping down his prose to make it as straightforward as possible, but in this book the novelist combines some fine description with believable dialogue to create a beautifully written work, conveying the grit and gore of war and the depth of the love between the two main characters.b) The strength of Hemingway's revulsion against the war. He stresses the damage to ordinary people and the way Italy's rulers exploited and betrayed those hundreds of thousands sent to die.c) The characterization of supporting persons. The dialogue with the Lieutenant's friends, the interplay with other nurses besides Catherine, the vignettes in restaurants and in the trenches -- all of this is played out with depth and atmosphere that make this book (in my view) one of the best that the author ever wrote.This all makes for a long book, especially compared to Hemingway's much later "Old Man and the Sea." But there is a raw authenticity to the novel that escaped some of the author's subsequent works. Hemingway became something of an icon in his later life, known as much for the public character that he built for himself as for his writing. "Unsheltered" is yet another fine book.At theBarbara Kingsolver has written many excellent novels (from "The Poisonwood Bible" to "Flight Behavior.") "Unsheltered" is yet another fine book.At the heart of it is a single house, and the two families that live in it over a hundred years apart. Willa Knox and her husband Iano are the centre of a complicated contemporary family of two adult children, Iano's ailing and belligerent father Nike, and now suddenly a new baby thrust on them by the postpartum suicide of the wife of Zeke, one of those adult children. Thatcher Greenwood and his wife Rose, in the house over a century before, have no children, but an equally belligerent parent (the mother of Rose) living unhappily with them. What links the two families is that each of them is confronted by damage and building failures that are in the process of destroying the house -- and leaving them unsheltered.Within this basic framework, Kingsolver tells a series of remarkable and ultimately intertwined stories. Both Thatcher and Willa face a series of difficult challenges (the former as a science teacher committed to teaching science in the face of religious fundamentalism, and the latter as the organizer of support for Nike, the new baby and her children.) Both also are married, but one finds his wife failing him so he looks for understanding from an intelligent and scientific woman neighbour -- while the love between Willa and Iano is what helps her surmount her difficulties.Parallel to these themes is an environmental emphasis that pervades the book. Greenwood and his neighbour Mary Treat (a historical figure who was an early biology researcher interacting with Charles Darwin) spend some of their most powerful scenes together in outdoor research sites. Tig,Willa's daughter, influenced by time spent in Cuba, is passionate about the dangers of global warming and the need to adopt an anti-consumption philosophy of living. Some of the most striking scenes involving Willa see her disposing of years of possessions so that she and Iano can move to a small apartment as their house falls down around them.No spoilers, so I won't discuss how Kingsolver's excellent plotting plays out. But with such interesting characters and significant themes, this book kept me entranced right to the end. I recommend it strongly. ...more

It's a long book (604 pages) and some of its format works better than other parts (I found the letters sent back and forth between two of the characters a little tedious at times.)
